text.0: true guardian of the law thy faithful servant wins ample light and dwells in peace o agni.
text.1: whom thou as varuṇa in accord with mitra guardest o god by banishing his trouble.
text.2: he hath paid sacrifices toiled in worship and offered gifts to wealthincreasing agni.
text.3: him the displeasure of the famous moves not outrage and scorn affect not such a mortal.
text.4: bright god whose look is free from stain like sūryas thou swift what time thou earnestly desirest.
text.5: hast gear to give us come with joy at evening where child of wood thou mayest also tarry.
text.6: fierce is his gait and vast his wondrous body he champeth like a horse with bit and bridle.
text.7: and darting forth his tongue as twere a hatchet burning the woods smelteth them like a smelter.
text.8: archerlike fain toshoot he sets his arrow and whets his splendour like the edge of iron.
text.9: the messenger of night with brilliant pathway like a treeroosting bird of rapid pinion.
text.10: in beams of morn he clothes him like the singer and bright as mitra with his splendour crackles.
text.11: red in the night by day the mens possession red he belongs to men by day immortal.
text.12: like heavens when scattering beams his voice was uttered among the plants the radiant hero shouted.
text.13: who with his glow in rapid course came hither to fill both worlds wellwedded dames with treasure.
text.14: who with supporting streams and rays that suit him hath flashed like lightning with his native vigour.
text.15: like the deft maker of the band of maruts the bright impetuous one hath shone refulgent.
